You know that noninteracting bosons form a Bose condensate: we will see how weak interactions alter this picture, and make a connection to the phenomenon of superfluidity.

The Gross--Pitaevskii Approximation

Our first attack on the problem is variational. It's very easy to come up with a variational wavefunction for the ground state of a Bose gas: put all the particles in the same single particle state!

(1)Ψ(r1,…rN)=∏j=1Nφ0(ri)=1N!(a†(φ0))N|VAC⟩.

A state with a macroscopic number of particles in a single particle state is known as a Bose condensate. You have probably studied the statistical mechanics of an ideal Bose gas before: the main feature is a condensation temperature below which macroscopic occupation occurs.

We know that if we have a noninteracting Hamiltonian

(2)H=∑[−∇i22m+V(ri)],

then the ground state has exactly the form (1), with φ0(r) the ground state of the single particle Hamiltonian. After adding interactions to the Hamiltonian, in the form

(3)Hint.=∑j<kU(rj−rk)=12∫dr1dr2U(r1−r2)ψ†(r1)ψ†(r2)ψ†(r2)ψ†(r1).

it is no longer true that the exact ground state has the form (1), but we can treat φ0(r) as a variational function that we must find. This leads to the Gross--Pitaevskii equation.

Gross--Pitaevskii Equation

From now on we will take a model of short-ranged interactions for simplicity

(4)U(r−r′)=U0δ(r−r′)

To implement the variational calculation we need to find

(5)⟨E⟩=⟨Ψ|H|Ψ⟩⟨Ψ|Ψ⟩

In fact, it turns out to be more convenient to minimize ⟨Ψ|H|Ψ⟩, using a Lagrange multiplier to fix the normalization. We have

(6)⟨Ψ|H|Ψ⟩=N∫dr[12m|∇φ0|2+V(r)|φ0(r)|2](7)+12N(N−1)U0∫dr|φ0(r)|4.

For large N, we can neglect the difference between N and N+1. Now we want to extremize this functional with respect to φ0(r), keeping φ0(r) normalized. To do this we introduce a Lagrange multiplier μN (the factor of N will become clear shortly) and extremize the functional

(8)⟨Ψ|H|Ψ⟩−μN∫dr|φ0(r)|2.

To find the extremum requires a standard application of the calculus of variations, yielding the equation

(9)[−12m∇2−μ+V(r)+NU0|φ0(r)|2]φ0(r)=0.

It's convenient to deal with the stray factor of N in (9) by defining φ(r)≡Nφ0(r). φ(r) is known as the condensate wavefunction or order parameter. Later we will give a more general definition that does not depend on the above variational approximation. We have thus obtained the Gross--Pitaevskii equation

(10)[−12m∇2−μ+V(r)+U0|φ(r)|2]φ(r)=0.

It remains to fix the Lagrange multiplier μ. This is done by demanding that ∫dr|φ(r)|2=N. Since ⟨Ψ|H|Ψ⟩−μ∫dr|φ(r)|2=⟨Ψ|H−μN|Ψ⟩ was extremized under general variations, including those that changed N, we must have

(11)μ=∂⟨Ψ|H|Ψ⟩∂N,

so that μ is identified with the chemical potential.

A fundamental effect of the nonlinearity of the GP equation is that there exists a length scale set by the typical value of |φ(r)|2∼n and the interaction strength

(12)ξ≡12mnU0

This healing length determines the scale over which φ(r) is disturbed by the introduction of a localized potential of scale ≪ξ. It is a fundamental length scale in the system.

Show that near a hard wall, where the condensate wavefunction goes to zero, φ(r) is given by

(13)φ(x)=φ∞tanh⁡x2ξ

where x is the distance from the wall, and φ∞=n∞ is fixed by the density of the condensate far from the wall.

Some Observables

With the ansatz (1) for the wavefunction, we can obtain various observables without difficulty. The density and current density are

(14)ρ(r)=|φ(r)|2,(15)j(r)=−i2m[φ∗(r)(∇φ(r))−(∇φ∗(r))φ(r)]

Alternatively, one may write this is terms of the velocity field of the gas, using j=ρv, and the decomposition of φ(r) into magnitude and phase

(16)φ(r)=ρ(r)eiθ(r).

We thus find the superfluid velocity

(17)vs≡1m∇θ.

The name is to distinguish this contribution from that arising from thermal excitations. For the moment we are considering zero temperature, so this is all there is.

The usefulness of the Gross--Pitaevskii equations lies in its ability to describe spatially nonuniform situations. Often, nonuniformity is imposed by an external potential, but there is an important class of configurations that are stable -- or metastable -- for topological reasons.

Example: Vortex

Since (17) tells us that the superfluid velocity is a gradient of something, we may expect it to be irrotational

(18)∇×vs=0,

or equivalently to have vanishing circulation

(19)∮vs⋅dl=0

around any closed loop. However, it is possible for the phase of the wavefunction to increase by a multiple of 2π around a closed loop, which still gives a single-valued condensate wavefunction since φ(r)=ρ(r)eiθ(r). Thus in general the circulation

(20)∮vs⋅dl=2πℓm,ℓ∈Z,

which is known as the Onsager--Feynmann quantization condition. A localized configuration with finite circulation is called a vortex in fluid dynamics, but in a normal fluid there is no reason for the vorticity to be quantized. Restoring Planck's constant just this once

(21)∮vs⋅dl=hℓm,ℓ∈Z,

shows that this is a truly quantum phenomenon.

A non-zero winding of the phase requires that ρ(r) vanishes at a point (in two dimensions) or on a line (in three). Let's see how such configurations are described by the Gross--Pitaevskii theory.

We are going to look for 2D solutions where the phase winds ℓ times as we encircle the origin

(22)φ(r,θ)→r→∞neiℓθ.

We parameterize the solution as φ(r,θ)=nf(r/ξ)eiℓθ, measuring distances in terms of the healing length. Substituting into the Gross--Pitaevskii equation gives an equation in s≡r/ξ.

(23)−f″−f′s+ℓ2fs2−f+f3=0.

We take μ=U0n to get the behaviour (22) at infinity.

Without finding the solution explicitly, show that f(s)∼sℓ for small s, and f(s→∞)→1.

The region of suppressed density, of characteristic size ξ, is called the vortex core. In three dimensions, the vortex core is a line.

We can find the energy of the vortex state by substituting the solution back into the energy functional (7) to find the energy excess relative to uniform state of density n

(24)ΔE=∫dr[n22mξ2(f′)2+U2n2(f2−1)2]+n2m∫drf2(∇θ)2.

The first integral is finite, and arises purely from the departure of the density away from its bulk value. The second represents the contribution to the kinetic energy arising from the winding of the vortex's phase. Since we have

(25)∇θ=ℓre^θ,

this contribution to the energy is logarithmically divergent.

(26)ΔE=const.+πnℓ2mlog⁡(Lξ).

There is far-reaching analogy between the superfluid velocity fields of vortices and the magnetostatics of current-carrying wires,

Vortices with |ℓ|>1 are generally unstable, and will break into multiple vortices of winding ℓ=±1. Like vortices repel each other, and can form spectacular vortex lattices, akin to crystals.

{{< figure src="3dLattices.jpg" title="Vortex lattice in a Bose--Einstein condensate of Sodium atoms. Source: Ketterle group, MIT." numbered="true" lightbox="true" >}}

Vortices are one manifestation of the phenomenon of superfluidity: persistent flow without resistance. The true ground state of the system does not have such flows, of course, so these flows are only metastable (as long as rotational symmetry is broken, so that angular momentum is not conserved). In the case of the vortex, it can only decay by its core leaving the system. An even simpler example is provided by currents flowing in a ring, a situation studied in Problem Set 2, which illustrates the important role played by repulsive interactions.

Bogoliubov Theory

How can we improve upon the Gross--Pitaevskii approximation? From now on we focus on a uniform condensate with no external potential V(r), in which case the condensate wavefunction is just a constant φ(r)=n. As usual we work in a plane wave basis, where the Hamiltonian takes the form

(27)H=∑kϵ(k)ak†ak†+U02V∑k1+k2=k3+k4ak1†ak2†ak3†ak4†⏞≡Hint,

with ϵ(k)=k2/2m, and V the volume. The Gross--Pitaevskii approximation to the ground state is

(28)|ΨGP⟩=1N!(a0†)N|VAC⟩.

When Hint acts on this state, the only terms that contribute are those with k3=k4=0

(29)Hint|ΨGP⟩=U02V∑kak†a−k†a0†a0†|ΨGP⟩.

Thus, if we want a better wavefunction, we are going to have to add some (k,−k) pairs!

Bogoliubov Hamiltonian

When interactions are weak, we expect that the true ground state is close to |ΨGP⟩, so that most of the particles remain in the zero momentum state, with relatively few pairs created. Remembering that

(30)a†|N⟩=N|N−1⟩,a†|N⟩=N+1|N+1⟩,

we see that a term in the Hamiltonian with a0† or a0† is going to be more important -- on account of the large occupancy of k=0 -- than a term without. For this reason we divide up the interaction Hamiltonian according to the number of occurrences of these operators

(31)Hint=U02Va0†a0†a0†a0†+U02V∑k≠0[ak†a−k†a0†a0†+a0†a0†ak†a−k†+4ak†a0†a0†ak†]+U0V∑k1=k2+k3k1,2,3≠0[ak3†ak2†ak1†a0†+a0†ak1†ak2†ak3†]+U02V∑k1+k2=k3+k4k1,2,3,4≠0ak1†ak2†ak3†ak4†.

The Gross--Pitaevskii approximation corresponds to the first term. We are now going to keep the second term, and neglect the third and fourth. Thus we study the Hamiltonian

Hpair=∑kϵ(k)ak†ak†+U02Va0†a0†a0†a0†(32)+U02V∑k≠0[ak†a−k†a0†a0†+a0†a0†ak†a−k†+4ak†a0†a0†ak†].

In fact, it's convenient to rewrite the second term of this Hamiltonian using

(33)a0†a0†=N−N′,N′≡∑k≠0Nk

so that

(34)a0†a0†a0†a0†=N(N−1)−2N′N0+O(N00).

In this approximation, we get

Hpair=∑kϵ(k)ak†ak†+U02VN(N−1)(35)+U02V∑k≠0[ak†a−k†a0†a0†+a0†a0†ak†a−k†+2ak†a0†a0†ak†].

Even now it's not so easy to solve this problem. One last vital simplification is needed. We are going to replace the operators a0†, a0† with N, giving a quadratic Hamiltonian. That may sound like a pretty odd thing to do: after all, the resulting Hamiltonian no longer conserves the number of particles! Let's see why this is a good approximation.

Consider the action of the Hamiltonian (32) on a product state of the form |Ψ′⟩⊗|N0⟩0, where we are 'factoring off' the Hilbert space of non-zero momentum states from the Fock state of the zero momentum state. The action of ak†a0† on this state is

(36)ak†a0†|Ψ′⟩⊗|N0⟩0=(ak†|Ψ′⟩)⊗a0†|N0⟩0=(ak†|Ψ′⟩)⊗N0|N0−1⟩0.

Likewise

(37)ak†a0†|Ψ′⟩⊗|N0⟩0=(ak†|Ψ′⟩)⊗a0†|N0⟩0=(ak†|Ψ′⟩)⊗N0+1|N0+1⟩0.

Since N0 is assumed to be large, we ignore the difference between N0 and N0+1. To be more precise, we are assuming that in the states we are going to find, N0 will not fluctuate substantially. If this is the case, the matrix elements of Hpair are approximately unchanged when we make the replacement mentioned above, leaving us with the Bogoliubov Hamiltonian

Hpair=∑kϵ(k)ak†ak†+U02VN(N−1)(38)+U0n02∑k≠0[ak†a−k†+ak†a−k†+2ak†ak†].

where n0=N0/V is the density of particles in the zero momentum state. The Hamiltonian (38) can be diagonalized by a Bogoliubov transformation

bp†=ap†cosh⁡κp+a−p†sinh⁡κptanh⁡2κp=n0U0ϵ(p)+n0U0.

The parameter κp of the transformation is chosen in order that there are no 'anomalous' bp†b−p† or bp†b−p† terms left in the Hamiltonian, which then takes the form of a sum of oscillators

(39)H=E0+∑p≠0ω(p)bp†bp†.

Here ω(p) is the Bogoliubov dispersion relation

(40)ω(p)=ϵ(p)(ϵ(p)+2U0n0),

and the ground state energy is

(41)E0=12nU0N+∑p≠012[ω(p)−ϵ(p)−n0U0].

Somewhat annoyingly, this integral is divergent in the ultraviolet. However, this is actually nothing to do with the many body physics of the problem, but is rather related to the need to regularize a δ-function potential in three dimensions. We can cure the problem by writing

(42)E0=12nU0N[1−1V∑pU02ϵ(p)]+∑p≠012[ω(p)−ϵ(p)−n0U0+(n0U0)22ϵ(p)].

In this form, the term we have added and subtracted is recognized as the next order in the Born approximation for the scattering length a=a0+a1+⋯. The second term can now be evaluated to give

(43)E0=12nN4πm(a0+a1)+12n0N4πma012815π(na03)1/2.

Where

(44)a0=(m/4π)U0,a1=−(m/4π)U02V∑p12ϵ(p).

The Ground State

So far, our ground state is just defined by the condition that it is a vacuum of Bogoliubov excitations

(45)bk†|0⟩=(cosh⁡κkak†+sinh⁡κka−k†)|0⟩=0.

But what does it look like? A state (unnormalized) that satisfies the above equation is

(46)|0⟩=∏k≠0exp⁡(−12tanh⁡κkak†a−k†)|ΨGP⟩

Show this. If you've seen coherent states before, remember that the state eαa†|VAC⟩ is an eigenstate of a† with eigenvalue α.

The form (46) shows explicitly that the state consists of a superposition of pairs excited out of the k=0 condensate. As we've discussed, we don't actually keep track of the loss of particles from the condensate in the Bogoliubov approximation, on the assumption that it is small.

We can get some feeling for the properties of the ground state by considering the density fluctuations. Recall that the Fourier components of the density operator are

(47)ρq=∑kak−q†ak†.

On the basis of the logic that we've been following so far, the most important terms will be those where one of ak−q† or ak† acts on the condensate. Thus

(48)ρq∼N(a−q†+aq†)=Ne−κq(b−q†+bq†),

where

(49)e−κq=ϵ(q)ω(q).

The density fluctuations in the ground state are then

(50)⟨0|ρ−qρq|0⟩=Nϵ(q)ω(q)→q→0N|q|2mc.

On the right hand side we have used the low momentum form of the Bogoliubov dispersion

(51)ω(q)→q→0c|q|

where c=n0U0m is the speed of sound. We see that the density fluctuations vanish as the wavevector goes to zero. This is to be contrasted with the result that we would find in the Gross--Pitaevskii ground state (or ground state of the ideal gas)

(52)⟨0|ρ−qρq|0⟩=N.

corresponding to uncorrelated, Poissonian fluctuations of number inside any volume of the gas. If we were to take a snapshot of the particles at any instant in the interacting gas, we would see a picture similar to the image of the Laughlin state in Lecture 1.

The other qualitatively new feature of the Bogoliubov ground state is that the zero momentum state is depleted. We find the momentum distribution by first writing the number operator Np=ap†ap† in terms of the Bogoliubov quasiparticles

(53)ap†ap†=(bp†cosh⁡κp−b−p†sinh⁡κp)(bp†cosh⁡κp−b−p†sinh⁡κp),

and then finding the average

(54)⟨Np⟩=⟨ap†ap†⟩=sinh2⁡κp→|p|≪ξ−1mcs2|p|.

The radial density distribution 4πp2Np is peaked around ξ−1. Summing over p gives the fraction of atoms not in the condensate

(55)1N∑p≠0⟨Np⟩=83πna3,

where we used the Born approximation for the scattering length a=mU04π. Excluding the value p=0 has no effect, because of the vanishing phase space at small momentum in three dimensions.

Under typical experimental conditions in experiments on ultracold atoms the depletion does not much exceed 0.01, which justifies the use of the GP approximation. Liquid He4, the first superfluid to be discovered, can be described as an interacting Bose condensate, but the depletion is much larger. The Bogoliubov approximation does not provide a quantiatively accurate description in this case.

In the previous lecture we met another situation where the depletion can be increased. Applying a lattice effectively reduces the kinetic energy relative to the interaction, and leads eventually to a quantum phase transition out of the superfluid state.
